B00005V3Z4|5.0|Hollywood's steady downfall into high-priced visual theatrics and recycled storylines with wittless characters has done nothing good except reestablish my faith in the underdog.  \\"Donnie Darko\\" in this case, is one of those underdogs - a completely morbid and fulfilling storyline, with dazzling presentation and a cast of amazing actors playing multi-layered characters.  <br />The story revolves around the charismatic, wayward teenager, Donnie Darko (Jake Gyllenhaal).  This troubled teen is the black sheep of his middle-class family, already having trouble with law for stealing a car and attending psycho-therapy sessions to handle his sleepwalking.  Only after a brief introduction into his life, does the movie immediately dive into the action - in a dream, Donnie is beckoned out of his house by an evil (almost satanic) looking man-sized bunny, Frank.  Frank tells Donnie that the world will end in 28 days - the 28th day being Halloween.  Back in reality, a jet-plane engine has fallen from the sky and crashed in Donnie's bedroom - Donnie survives because he had been sleepwalking.  Frank becomes a regular figure in Donnie's dreams and delusions - coercing him to commit random acts of vandalism and arson.  In the meantime, the world around Donnie Darko seems embedded with strange characters, mind-bending encounters and philosphical if not humorously poignant conversations.  Among these are are Jim Cunningham (Patrick Swayze), the self-help guru, his highschool teachers: (Noah Wyle) - who is obsessed with the ideas of time travel - and (Drew Barrymore) who is disillusioned with the education system feeding into Jim Cunnigham , Grandma Death -a prophet of some sorts and Gretchen (Jena Malone), Donnie's new girlfriend and another troubled teen, who's mother is hiding out from an abusive ex-husband.  As doomsday approaches, Donnie's visits from Frank the evil bunny become more frequent, as he points out the relivance of time travel in his visits into Donnie's psyche.  Soon,Donnie realizes that many of his encounters with Frank, leave very real impacts on those around him.  (Spoiler:  For instance, Frank tells Donnie to burn down Jim Cunningham's house, that reveals a child pornography ring in his basement).  <br />All events and characters lead Donnie down to his final day, where he realizes that certain events have to take place and some people must suffer in order for others to survive.<br />\\"Donnie Darko\\" is magnificant in keeping one's interest, keeping its audience in suspense and sometimes in laughter.  Jake Gyllenhaal does a superb job of playing Donnie as a dark confused teenager in search of understanding and conscious, with the sexiness of Tobey Maguire but with a personality.  The dynamics of family make this story seem very real and close to home, as we are not only drawn to the supernatural, but to the plight of Donnie's mother, who is desperate to guide and understand her son.  <br />The basic story, visual effects and music are simple and play well off each other.  However, the much greater story and concept is certainly hard to understand and up for interpretation.  With time travel being a major theme, one might need to watch through the movie two or three times to finally have an idea of what actually happened in what order.  The ending (no spoiler, sorry!) can leave one with the questions: what just happened?... What did he accomplish? But the movie has enough of an impact and plain entertainment value, that I doubt anyone will complain about watching it over again.  <br />This movie is superb for a drinking games, Halloween parties or just sitting back and watching one stormy evening.  If you haven't seen it yet - you're missing out.  One day, film makers will try to imitate the magical properties that \\"Donnie Darko\\" has captured in about two hours.
B00006ZCFH|4.0|ERYKAH BADU'S fourth release entitled &quot;Worldwide Underground&quot; is a hard listen at first. With a second listen i realized how much i liked this release. A throbbing bumping bass drum beat turns into a mid tempo jazz jam in the middle. Badu switches gears with the best of them. The music is always controlled. The downfall of the cd is that given Badu's incredible range with her voice (just listen to 1998's &quot;LIVE&quot; release) she doesnt just stand still and belt. As powerful and meaningful as her lyrics are her worldplay and jazzy style can be tiring. Her voice is versatile and should be used as such more often. But that doesnt drag this release down too much. With bumping laid back tracks it is sure to please any fan of hip hop soul and the neo-soul movement.
0767817710|4.0|I will first agree with the negative aspects. This is not a western. As much as it looks like one, it really isn't. The dialogue could be easily placed in a new york gang atmosphere and flow fine. The way the characters act and their mannerisms doesn't fit the time period either. This I agree with.<br />But lay off it a bit guys. I can understand if you're fully gung-ho on westerns, and if theres one film thats masked as a western but actually contains more satire, you blow your top and dub the film a fake and a horrible act of God. True, there is a style of the great Sergio Leone's \\"The Good The Bad, And The Ugly\\", but that wasn't a western either. Spaghetti westerns were films that took place in the wild wild west, but were actually filmed in Italy, where they really had no clue what the west was like. So most of those westerns had a \\"light-heartedness\\" to them. Sergio Leone was famous for making a western seem comical. And I believe, Mr. Raimi just took that idea and did it again. Only this time with his directing flair, which is so fun to watch, I wet myself everytime I watch it (lets flash to the fight scene between spiderman and green goblin, supposed to be serious, but actually very light-hearted). During a showdown, Raimi would do an excessive amount of fast zooms on everything! The two guys fighting, the people watching, an inanimate object. I was laughing so hard! And of course, who can forget when the bad guy finally gets what he deserves via Raimi's trademark. POV of bullet! BAM! right in the face, followed by an \\"Army of Darkness\\" flip for a finale. My point is, this film is not meant to be taken seriously. But the plot was horribly serious, and Gene Hackman plays an evil man very well, nothing like his cowardly Lex Luthor role (bad analogy, my friend). So the mixture of the serious plot with the directing didn't quite fit. But thanks to Raimi, this film is filled with whacky camera angles, and comic uber spaghetti western themes. Thicker than spaghetti, linguine. Enjoy it!

B00006F7S4|5.0|If anyone were to dare proclaim a musician 'today's equivalent of the Beatles', they would be hard-pressed to find a more worthy candidate than Beck.  Many of his talents are apparent from just a single listen: assured lyrics and melodies; deceptively virtuoso, chameleon vocals; rich, imaginative, respectfully derivative production and style...but the real comparison lies in his ability to reinvent himself, and his commitment to doing just that with each consecutive album.<br />This album is the quietest and perhaps most powerful Beck album I'm familiar with.  The bold satiricism of Midnight Vultures undergoes a 'sea change' into what could be called an 'older' Mutations.  If Mutations was a college student, vibrantly cynical and playfully yet bitterly sarcastic...then Sea Change graduated a long time ago.  It's subdued and achingly genuine; still sarcastic, but in the way someone truly wounded would half crack a joke out of habit or a desire to retain a degree of dignity.  If I were to sum up the tone in one word, it would be weary.  This isn't Beck the young poet prodigy, spontaneously spinning out webs of slicing observation borne of innate insight or keen wit.  This is Beck the experienced storyteller, aged beyond his years, reflecting helplessly on events and emotions that aren't theories, but tangible, often cruel overseers of the psyche's landscape and all that toils upon it.<br />Stylistically, this weariness is reflected in simple chords and progressions that become a kind of cradle, understated, sincere vocals, and seamlessly integrated references to country that bolster the inherent tone and content.  I wouldn't call myself a country fan, and mostly because of the very elements Beck here uses to such mesmerizing effect.  Give it a listen; anyone who's ever felt heartbroken, or tired, can't help but feel understood.
B000002H33|5.0|A lot of reviewers hesitate to place Master of Puppets at the beginning of the list of greatest metal albums.  You'll see it referred to as &quot;one of the greatest&quot; or &quot;possibly the greatest&quot;.  I have no such hesitation - this is THE greatest metal album ever crafted.  Metallica achieves this by seamlessly combining their trademark thrash with polished lyrics and haunting melodies.  The result is timeless songs that are often imitated and covered, but never surpassed.  It's no coincidence that a number of Metallica classics and concert mainstays are<br />taken from this album.  In addition, the shear variety of songs appeals to all preferences.  For those who love unrelenting thrash metal, we have &quot;Battery&quot; and &quot;Disposable Heroes&quot;.  For those who prefer a more somber, haunting tone, there is &quot;Welcome Home (Sanitarium)&quot;.  For those who like metal ballads, there is the title track.<br />For those who favor Metallica's post-Black Album work, you do yourself a disservice by not picking up this album.  This is Metallica at their finest, and I give it my highest possible recommendation.

B00008X5J3|4.0|Roxie Hart, as played by Renee Zellweger, craves to become a famous musical comedy star.  Roxie's boy friend promises to introduce her to his buddy who supposedly has connections in show biz.  The only thing Roxy's friend desires is to jump into the sack with her--nothing else.  When Roxy is faced with his lies, she takes her revenge.    Thus begins the story of \\"Chicago,\\" the razzle-dazzle musical about people who will seek fame at any price, whether via show business or indictment and trial for murder.  Either one of these is sure to grab headlines.  Richard Gere's character, the more than slightly sleezy lawyer, Billy Flynn, is more than happy to represent Roxy Hart, for a price.  Flynn also represents the singer/dancer and fellow felon, Velma Kelly, portrayed by Catherine Zeta-Jones, who is in competition with Roxy Hart for renown.      The premise of \\"Chicago,\\" and a very cynical one, is how the press, hungry to sell newspapers, often thrust those least deserving into stardom.  Fame is fleeting; once the public gets bored with the latest flavor of the month, the media move on to the next flavor.  Note the case of O.J. Simpson, and his would  replacement, Robert Blake.  Of course, in between, Osama Bin Laden was abruptly forgotten in \\"favor\\" of Sadaam Hussein.    \\"Chicago\\" is a truly entertaining and enjoyable film.  Catherine Zeta-Jones, who, in real life is an honest to goodness singer and dancer, is simply wonderful as Velma Kelly.  Zeta-Jones' rendition of \\"All That Jazz\\" is a show stopper.  Renee Zellweger lends a little girlish quality (ala Marilyn Monroe) to her scandalously trampish portrayal.  Richard Gere's performance as the lawyer has just the right touch of slickness required by the role.  It is quite gratifying that although neither Zellweger or Gere are profesional dancers, they both turn in applaud-worthy and polished performances.  John C. Reilly, as Roxy's hapless and cuckolded husband, does a heartbreaking turn in his number, \\"Mr. Celophane,\\"the man everyone sees through because no one knows he is there.  Queen Latifah steals the show as the \\"lets make a deal\\" prison matron.  She is sexy and deliciously sardonic when she takes center stage in \\"When You're Good To Mama.\\"    My only criticism of \\"Chicago\\" is that while the musical numbers are often terrific, the movie too often feels a little bit overloaded with them.  I also often asked myself, \\"Is the public really so naive that they would fall for such obvious phonies\\" as dramatized in the film?  I guess that some people do have the need to identify with the latest, current fad, even if, as Andy Warhol said, the fame is over in 15 minutes.

B0000AXE8I|5.0|Whenever anyone enters into a serious discussion about movies either contemporary or old, The Matrix is always mentioned and compared to other movies at some point.  The Matrix Reloaded, along with its predecessor, will be looked upon years from now much in the same way we now look at Casablanca or Lawrence of Arabia.  The Matrix I and II really are extraordinary, both in terms of plot complexity and cinematic ingenuity.<br />The people who give The Matrix I and II bad reviews often say that the plot is shallow or not there altogether.  Most modern movies have the tendency to treat the audience like idiots and make the plot extremely easy to understand and follow, giving the audience a false perception of how deep the plot really is.  The Matrix does not do this.  Instead, the idea behind the Matrix is a philosophical one, one that you must ponder deeply in order to follow.  For some people whose cinematic taste buds have unfortunately been burned by movies such as Swordfish or Predator, this movie comes as an offense to everything they are used to.  Inevitably, therefore, many people will dislike this movie trilogy.<br />So, if you are tired of the same old action/violence/sex movies that Hollywood pumps out these days in order to make the most money, you must see The Matrix I and II.  They contain philosophy, social commentary, and in conjunction with artistic special effects, redefine modern cinema.

B00004TCPJ|5.0|Rachmaninoff was a great friend and mentor to Horowitz and they shared an affinity for melody, beautiful sound, wide dynamics, huge range of tonal colors, and drama.  I think this is a very beautiful recording of the concerto.  Though not as brilliant as the recording he made with Reiner in 1951, it sure is a better sounding recording.  It isn't that there is anything wrong with it, in fact it is brilliant, it is just that this older Horowitz had lost a bit on his fastball as it were.  But this is the recording, in its original LP release, is the one that I first heard this concerto and fell immediately in love and it still holds a tremendous amount of magic for me, especially since it is a live performance.  However, if you want to hear the peak of the Horowitz virtuosity get the RCA Victor Gold Seal Disk #7754.  It has the same recording of the Sonata, but adds some smaller works.  It is worth everything just for the recording of the Concerto #3 even if you duplicate the sonata.<br />The sonata is also a fabulous live recording.  The opening massiveness with its crash and roar is a pianistic sound I have never heard any other pianist make as convincingly in any place at any time.  It is absolutely unique in my experience and the whole performance is blindingly wonderful.  Horowitz has not only fused two versions that Rachmaninoff played, he also made some other changes he felt the composer would approve.  I believe him.<br />Be aware that even in live recordings, Horowitz would edit together multiple performances and could be very demanding in approving the final version.<br />Get this disk and enjoy these pieces.  It is great pianism and I believe it is something you should want to have in your collection.

B0000AI44Q|5.0|I saw the Greendale Tour this summer. At first I was highly disappointed. I am a huge Neil Young fan, but I couldn't believe that he was performing a new album. It wasn't until &quot;Leave the Driving&quot; that the music and the concept began to work on me. That concert was one of the most amazing concerts of my life. Neil has tremendous guts to be playing a new album in rock opera form when he could easily be putting out albums that sound like Harvest and just play his greatest hits in concert, like the majority of the classic rock stars. Instead he took a risk, and it worked (I should note that the second act of the concert contained a mini &quot;Rust Never Sleeps&quot; set as well as other Young classics). The album is equally amazing. Neil tells the story of a family and a town as a metaphor for the human condition, illustrating themes that are timeless and current. Listen closely, and you will hear a critique of the Bush Administrations policies(i.e. patriot act, environment, energy policy) as well as timeless themes like the importance of family, the wisdom of the elderly, and the idealistic energy of youth. The album ends with a call to take action. Neil sings &quot;We've got a job to do&quot;. Given the times we live in, and the policy that is being passed while most are numb with distraction, Neil's words are an urgent call to protect and transform the world.

B00003CXBH|4.0|Nominated for seven Academy Awards and taking in one for &quot;Best Cinematography&quot;, THE MISSION is director Roland Joffe's interesting drama.  Based on fact and scripted by Robert Bolt, the film is set in 18th century Spain, where a ruthless slave-trader (Robert De Niro) becomes a Jesuit as the Europeans attempt to remove the Portuguese from the land.  De Niro is excellent, but without the action of his normal performances, he's almost boring; Jeremy Irons as his &quot;mentor&quot; is terrific as well; there's also a good if not small performance by a young Liam Neeson, among others.  Ennio Morricone has a smooth, moving score that works well with the film's misty, sometimes relaxing production design. 0316666343|3.0|Lovely Bones, in my opinion, is not the story of Susie Salmon.  Rather, it seems to me that the author is trying to tell a bigger story, incorporating all of Susie's family.  (The title itself refers to the larger framework of what holds the family together.)  In attempting to tell a story of this scope, however, I think Sebold took on too much.  <br />For myself and many of the other readers, the book lost its claim on us once we got beyond its initial impact.  Is our focus the strain that threatens her parent's marriage?  What about Susie's sister?  her wacky but well-meaning grandmother?  Sebold would have done well to either limit the number of characters we follow, or limit the length of time in which we follow them.  Lindsey, Susie's sister, is a very spirited and interesting character at first.  By the time we've followed her to college, her character's essence has been so severely diluted that it's almost nonexistent.  <br />Within this unsatisfying whole, I did discover some gems such as the idea that, from crisis to crisis, a huband or wife usually has the other to \\"be strong\\" for them.  The tragedy of a murdered child, however, is a tidal wave that spins them apart even as it comes crashing down on their heads.  <br />I enjoyed the simple heaven of crayola colors that Sebold gives us; this certainly seems like heaven through the eyes of a schoolchild.  Of course heaven has swings!  <br />I also appreciate how Sebold blends eerie possibility into this fictional tale when Susie's young brother, Buckley, sees his sister.  Many people have observed something like this!  After my mother died, my young nephew would regularly look into the corner of the living room and smile.  <br />Unfortunately, I'm afraid Sebold lost control over her story when Susie returns to Earth.  To me, the \\"body-switch\\" feels false and out-of-synch.   For one thing, I can't accept that a girl who had been violated would experience her happiness through sex. <br />Don't let the hype getyou!  This book may boast an intriguing  premise, but it fails to maintain its promise.

B0000636UN|3.0|Fresh off her triumphant Daisy Mae tour, \\"Sheryl Crow\\" (born Camilla Borghardt) changes gears and offers her fans something new on this, her sophomore effort. It's a gallimaufrical potpourri of loci delicti, garnished with an unexplained residuum of blank intervals, its harshness softened somewhat by elliptical postmodernish referencing strategies. And therein lies its weakness. Had she been content to simply neutralize the listening public's heedless indifference to global hegemonicization through inert fantasies of illusory dominance, she might have produced a masterpiece of indiscriminate flatulence; as it is, however, she oversteps the boundaries of academic propriety and perpetrates (or perpetuates?) only another sesquipedalian solicitation, the kind we have heard far too much of from such inferior monstrosities as Grand Funk Railroad and Ernst Krenek. Witness, per exemplum, her bitonal confection \\"Whisper Sex into Me\\" (track 19), in which the first subject confines itself to recapitulating a double-subdominant motif in A-flat, while the second subject consists of nothing more than our old friend the Alberti bass, endlessly reitereiterating its stultifying banalities in C-sharp minor. Doubtless we are intended to marvel at its audacious \\"incompetence\\" and then be brought up short by the sudden realization that we've been \\"had\\"...that Camilla has been toying with our deflated expectations all along! Yawn. Been there, done that (as my 12-year-old wife likes to say). As it is, this is merely a complemental album for the masses, who are willing to stew in their concupiscence. Those of us with more homologous tastes may prefer to wait it out.

0792841344|5.0|Probably the best cult horror/sci-fi film ever made.  Combines a boogie man (Tall Man), corpses crushed down into hooded, very ugly dwarfs and, scariest of all, the fear of a 14 year old boy that he will be left alone in the world. Instead, they arm themselves heavily and cruise around in a black muscle car looking to crack some skulls.  <br />If you are a film student, or just love film, the extras on this DVD are worth the purchase.  A truly amazing story of a 23 year old director (Don Coscarelli) who made a truly independent film, using money borrowed from neighbors and his parents.  The total budget was $ 300,000.  While the effects are sometimes corny, the overall mood created, and especially the haunting score, make it look like anything but a &quot;B&quot; horror film. The cast is riddled with relatives and friends lending a hand.<br />Phantasm 2 isn't bad, but 3 and 4 do a diservice to the original.<br />BUY THIS MOVIE.
0440178002|4.0|This book is--as my dear old Grandma would have said--a ripper.  In case you are one of the 9 people who haven't heard of it, it is a consistently-entertaining adventure/political intrigue story set in medieval Japan at the dawn of the Shogun era, just prior to the expulsion of Europeans from the Japanese home islands.  It is based on the true story of William Adams who, as near as I can find out (there appears to be precious little in English on the man) really did sail to &quot;The Japans&quot; in the early 17th century, and did indeed become a samurai.  But as others point out, it ain't history, and it isn't a language lesson, either.  It also purportedly contains anachronistic touches, such as the highly-stylized samurai code (which apparently wasn't codified until quite a bit later), and so on.<br />That aside, it's a pile of fun.  This isn't &quot;great literature&quot; by any stretch, but it's interesting and engrossing.  It's a bit too long, weighing in at something close to 900 pages, but if you are fascinated by the Japanese medieval culture, or by the political intrigue of the Elizabethan era, you'll enjoy this.  If digression from accepted history bothers you, or a somewhat-windy style of writing irritates you, give it a miss.  But speaking personally, this is the only Clavell novel that I've really been able to get into, and I've even re-read it a number of times.

First time director and first time screenwriters, what can you expect?<br />The script was just not believable. I know that romantic comedies have the liberty of taking some license here and there, but I just didn't buy so much of this movie that the whole thing just seemed fake. For starters, we're supposed to believe that Jennifer Lopez is an Italian immigrant? Come on! Her father (Alex Rocco (I)) doesn't sound Italian, he sounds retarded. I don't even know why she had to be an immigrant. There was nothing in the plot that required her being from another country, except for the fact that her father trys to arrange a marriage, which was just another unnecessary plot device. There's just so much that was wrong with this script, I'm just amazed that the leading actors signed on to this project.<br />The talent in this movie was fairly decent. Jennifer Lopez and Matthew McConaughey had some chemistry and they looked good together. Kathy Najimy is a wonderful comedic actress and her scene with Jennifer was very good and believable. Fred Willard, and Kevin Pollak are the other actors that do comedic roles extremely well, but their talents were simply not tapped. They did what they could, but they simply had nothing to work with. IMHO I think Jennifer Lopez signed on because she was friends with Adam Shankman (he's a choreographer) and once she signed on, everyone else jumped on board for their resume.

B00003CWTI|4.0|This movie is not for the faint of heart. I made the mistake of starting this movie at 10:30pm thinking that it'd be the usual 1.5 hour movie. I should have looked at the sleeve more closely, this movie is over 3 hours long. Not to mention the fact that Anderson pushes the boundaries of storytelling by interweaving a multitude of characters to tell one story, or message. This is a &quot;thinking man's&quot; movie and not something to just flip through like so many movies released today.<br />The script is great, but Anderson has also put together a fantastic cast to bring it to life. John C. Reilly, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Philip Baker Hall are some of the best character actors around and they just light up the screen. Tom Cruise who gives a stand out performance as Frank T.J. Mackey (host of an infomercial called &quot;Seduce and Destroy&quot;), Julianne Moore, William H. Macy round out the cast and bring a little star power along with them. But there are a ton of more actors in this ensemble piece, such as Jason Robards, but the list is simply too long to list.<br />It's so hard to review this film, simply because it is told in such a unique way. All of the characters are connected to one another in some way shape and form and Anderson uses a variety of styles to tell the story. In fact, at one point, it's almost a music video as all of the major characters lip sync to one of the cuts from the soundtrack. This movie is funny, sad, poignant, and absurd. It's simply one of those films that you'll be talking about days after seeing it, still trying to put all the pieces together. Overall, this film is a movie lover's feast. A feast full of rich a delectable tastes. Dig in.

I would have preferred to find out about Nick Drake's music in a less commercial, indirect way, but oh well. As a matter of fact, that commercial is one of the few car commercials I can actually watch all the way through without wanting to vomit uncontrollably on my television screen. The odds of getting stranded on an island is really unlikely considering that the majority of us dont frequent islands on a regular basis and getting stranded on an island isn't high on the list of \\"things that we are afraid of...\\" But, IF it were to ever happen, you'd want to be prepared in advance and have your copy of Nick Drake's \\"Pink Moon\\" readily available at all times.  Forget about dispensable items such as food and water, you'll die happy having this album along.

The movie's story starts out as mysterious and powerful aliens launch an all-out invasion of the human race.  The movie begins when several radio areas across the world recieve a transmission from the moon that sounds just like bees buzzing themselves out. Then at the Pentagon, they recieve pictures of the largest spaceships that are wider than the Enterprise of Star Trek. Even worse, they disrupt TV reception and satellites, too. The spaceships are 15 miles in width, enough to encompass an entire city. David, a computer whiz from New York finds an alien program hidden in the satellites, and precisely six hours from now, the alien ships will attack every major city all over the planet. That includes Los Angeles, New York, and Washington D.C.  Then, at approximately six hours later, the aliens fire their destructive weapons at the major cities all over the planet, causing big fires ten times than in actual fires and people dying in the process. Three of the funniest lines are: \\"We want you dead!\\", \\"Oh No, you didn't shoot that green crap at me\\", and \\"All right you alien animals... in the words of my generation, up yours!\\" are especially amusing.

B00000AFHM|5.0|It's now five years since this album was released and so we now have considerable hindsight on our side to give this album a more well-rounded look.  Since it was released, Belle and Sebastian became, thanks in part to a memorable scene in the movie High Fidelity, the band of choice to savage for showing any kind of vulnerability or sensitivity in the sound, both musically and lyrically.  And so they unfairly became the band most likely to provide the soundtrack for depressed teenagers to write poetry in their bedrooms to, which does a disservice to such imaginative music.  It's very telling that most of the negative reviews for this album on this site tend to attack the band's listeners as much as the band itself.  Yes, there is a gentleness here that's not for everyone.  But The Boy With the Arab Strap definitely falls into the category of &quot;timeless masterpieces,&quot; due primarily to its fascinating arrangements and overall quality.<br />Words like &quot;twee&quot; and &quot;fey&quot; and &quot;precious&quot; are tossed around by those out for blood, but anyone who takes the time to listen will hear a wealth of interesting instrumentation, great melodies, and probably the most diversity ever displayed on one of their albums.  For that reason I'd easily crown it the band's best (and I have heard the newest one, Dear Catastophe Waitress).  <br />Highlights for me are The Rollercoaster Ride for its quiet catchiness and hypnotic piano part which comes in halfway and never lets up; the title track for its unfailing ability to get the toe tapping; Chickfactor for its beautiful rolling keyboard and aching strings; Sleep the Clock Around with its great use of bagpipe, and Dirty Dream Number Two for rivalling Spector in its huge wall of sound.<br />Best of all, it endures, and I suspect it will never sound dated and will make Top 100 Albums lists for years to come.  Pretty rare.

B0000BYM3K|3.0|Much like many people on here, I was incredibly disappointed by the new album. The cover artwork is absolutely, undeniably the most godawful thing I've seen in forever (folks might have been impressed with horrendous computer art in 1991?), the songs aren't as catchy as they are on BNW, and the production is weak. I'll leave the cover alone since anyone who's got a smidgen of brains shudders at the sight of it.<br />The album has grown on me the more I listened, though I'm definitely grooving more on the overall feel as opposed to specific songs, which tends to contradict almost every other Maiden album I enjoy (ie, everything except No Prayer For The Dying and any of the Blayze albums). The first song is nothing special, but isn't bad. The second track is definitely one of my favorites, with an excellent chorus and some great guitar parts. The fourth would be great if I didn't keep wincing every time the chorus and guitar start doing the same thing (haven't winced that hard since the prechorus to Die With Your Boots On). There are definitely way too many tracks that have the slow building start. I don't mind how Maiden has decided to make their songs longer, but the problem is, if the song isn't that mind-blowing, its fairly annoying to have to sit through 8 minutes of it. I enjoyed how long the tracks on BNW were, but almost everything on this album could afford to be shaved down quite a bit, especially considering there is a great lack of catchy choruses. <br />The drums are much quieter in the mix this time, and the bass is much mellower, allowing the three guitars to stand out more. Unfortunately, much like BNW, they aren't really doing that much with them. Where are all the harmonies and parts playing off of each other? If there was any band I'd like to have three guitarrists, its Maiden, but for goodness' sake, use them!<br />The only reason I'm giving this guy three stars is because those few amazing numbers (2, 9, 10) are really quite good.<br />I find thisis an album I like to put on and ignore. Which certainly has its place, but up until this point putting on a Maiden album has been in order to sing along and rock out and get energized. I still think this is the aim of the band, but if it is, it certainly failed.
B000000W9Z|5.0|This is one evil mother of a jazz/lounge/industrial/rock/ambient/darkwave album. It's got great hooks, dark corners, hip-shaking house-raisers and some of Bowie's best lyrics(\\"Stay away from the future/Don't tell God your plans/It's all deranged/No control.\\") Eno's stark soundscapes, Garson's elegant and hypnotic piano and keyboard work, Garbrel's guitar witchery and Bowie's paranoid \\"conceptualism\\"(not to mention David's knack for putting together great studio bands) make for a delightfully nocturnal, surreal and \\"underwordly\\" painting. \\"The Motel\\" is one the most unsettling and fragile tracks ever crooned by Bowie: gloriously tragic and dramatic...a swinging heartbreak. \\"A Small Plot Of Land\\" is a rattling, shuffling, skittering, soaring creature of a jazz track...it's a like a nightmare running thru the night. Bowie still loves to put the funk down and he does it in spades with \\"I Have Not Been To Oxford Town\\". \\"We Prick You\\" patters about creepily like a mesquito. \\"Wishful Beginings\\" is just as creepy. The little spoken-word interludes I could do without, but every actual song this album is perfectly perfect. It's so interesting to see David melding progressive jazz with glitch and rock. It makes for a pleasureably brooding listen.

Not her first year to bring so much controversy, 2003 saw Madonna heavily influenced by personal problems and the war in Iraq. April saw the release of Madonna's latest studio album, \\"American Life,\\" which topped the charts in both the US and UK and has sold more than 5 million copies worldwide to date. The first song from the album was the self-titled American Life. The song flopped big style in the US, due to lack of airplay as many stations refused to play the song due to Madonna's comments on President Bush and his regime. The song peaked at No.2 in the UK singles charts, but did not spend more than one week in the Top 10.<br /><br />American Life begins with Madonna singing, \\"Do I have to change my name? This type of modern life is not for free.\\" For Madonna, it's an incredibly long verse. Madonna then sings the chorus a few more times as the song crashes and dies down.<br /><br />The video to American Life cause tons of controversy back in the spring of 2003. Madonna originally shot an elaborate video to the song involving a catwalk and war victims to connect the link of war and fashion. By the time the video was due to be shown, however, the war in Iraq had already begun and Madonna - for the first time in her career - back down out of doing something out of respect. Obviously, Madonna then had her critics calling her a coward for pulling out. She wasn't - she was bowing out in respect. A much cheaper video was shot with world flags in the background. The controversy over American Life hasn't done much for Madonna's reputation of career in 2003, and we can only hope that Madonna comes back bigger, better and strong next year. 0486409511|5.0|After studying calligraphy through workshops and lessons since 1989, I decided to add Copperplate to my repertoire. I found learning this style requires a whole new &quot;think&quot; on writing:  different flexible pen nibs, pen angles, paper slant, stops, bold and hairline strokes, and of course incredible(albeit refined)embellishment. This book holds prime position in my library, is ink-stained and spotted, has pages unbound from overuse, and is the most perfect way to learn this hand as any I have ever seen.  Every time I want to use Copperplate on a commission or project, I haul it out to have beside me, to remember all the little specifics that make Copperplate so beautiful.  I love this book!

031286504X|4.0|The story I Am Legend is a very well-written vampire story with a nice twist.  It's not the usual vampire hunter type book, but ends up making you look at things from two different points of view.  It's amazing that the author can keep the reader interested and captivated in the story of one single man.  As an avid reader of Anne Rice, Stephen King, and Dean Koontz, I was apprehensive at first about this novel, but ended up being very satisfied.  The other stories in the book are hit or miss, some better than others.  He does have an interesting writing style and interesting ideas.  Some of his short stories were a little on the windy side, but all in all he's a rare mind.  Definitely worth picking up and reading the whole thing though, especially I Am Legend.

Bruce Dickinson still sounds amazing and some songs on the CD such as &quot;Dance of Death&quot; and &quot;No More Lies&quot; show that he can go mellow if need be. &quot;Paschendale&quot; is, hands down, the best song on the album, an 8 minute epic. &quot;New Frontier,&quot; Nicko McBrain's writing debut is also excellent. There is not one bad track on this album. Is it as good as, say, Piece of Mind? No. It does not compare to the classic albums of the 80's, but it is still worth buying. 4 stars, UP THE IRONS!!!
B00003CXBK|5.0|I used to think that Disney put out truly great animation that touches the souls of those who watch it, that is until I watched this film.  Disney has done at least one good thing in the last few years, which is to bring Mononoke and other Miyazaki movies to America.  I applaud them for it, even if they don't always appreciate the masterpieces that they are selling.<br />Princess Mononoke is an anime movie, but in many ways it is beyond anime.  Although it is steeped in Japanese history and mythology, this is a film that has meaning for  people of every culture, dealing with universal themes such as ecological preservation and the often self-destructive ways  of human nature.  It even comments on the relationship between men and women.  All are subjects that American movies have tried to contemplate before but not with nearly as much intelligence or respect for the audience.  There are no real villians here, creeping around with their evil intentions; not once does the audience feel that they are being preached to about Right and Wrong.  Mikyazaki simply presents characters who are doing the best they can in a bad situation, as all people do in real life.  Granted, in real life, raging Forest Gods aren't trying to kill you.  But suspension of disbelief is easy to acheive when you have a meaningful story line and characters that people can actually care about.  <br />The animation is simple compared to Spirited Away, but is just as beautiful and fits well with the starker atmosphere of the movie.  A lot of it reminds me of old Japanese paintings.  I'm glad to say that there was a minimum of computer animation used in this film and the whole movie has a rich hand drawn feel.  The score by Joe Hisaishi is simply grand (I'll plug the soundtrack while I'm at it); since I've seen this movie I'm not only a Miyazaki fan, but also a devoted Hisaishi listener. <br />It's a shame, then, that such a perfect movie would be given such a mediocre dubbing job.  Disney did just whatI expected they would do. . . they chose actors based on their names and not on how  well they portrayed the characters.  It's pretty obvious that those in charge had publicity in mind when they cast Billy Bob Thornton, of all people, as a Japanese monk.  Claire Danes is too whiny and childish to play the dour San, and Billy Crudup is just dull in the lead role of Ashitaka.  I will give credit to Minnie Driver, however, the only one among them who did as good a job as her Japanese counterpart.  Driver is a dead ringer for the sophisticated and strong-willed Eboshi.<br />Regardless, I suggest this movie not only to anime fans but to anyone who likes a good story and strong characters who don't adhere to Hollywood conventions.  Take the time to read the subtitles.  I should warn that there is some gore and violence, but it is used tastefully and in regards to the plot.
B00008J2PG|4.0|Great Job ... Acting, Location & Story.  Its nice to see one more positive telling of the Church during the war.  Not too many people know that the Chief Rabi of Rome during and immediately after the war, Israel Zolii, was so impressed by the Christians in Rome who tried to protect Jews from nazi persecution, that he was baptised as Catholic shortly after the end of the war.  He took for his Christian name Eugene ... the same first name as Pope Pius XII, whom he especially admired as a friend and protector of Jews. He died as a devout Catholic.

B00008EY9G|4.0|Just when you are about to lose hope for the future of the film industry, someone comes out with a smart movie for adults that despite playing into the slasher genre does so with unusual aplomb.<br />With nods to Hitchock's &quot;Psycho&quot; and Agatha Christie's &quot;And Then There Were None,&quot; &quot;Identity&quot; gives us a creepy desert motel soon populated by a host of folks stranded by an unrelenting rain storm that has washed out the roads. A car accident brings in Ed (John Cusack - a burned out ex-cop), now chauffeuring an insufferable C-movie actress from shoot to shoot (an unrecognizable Rebecca DeMornay), and a family of three for first aid. Unable to use the phones to call for assistance, Ed is forced to drive to the local hospital. Along the way, he picks up Paris (Amanda Peet - doing an updated version of Janet Leigh's character in &quot;Psycho&quot;, but without the shower scene), and a very newly married couple, all three stranded at the eastern end of the washed out highway. With no options, they head back to the motel.<br />The back story of the film follows an inquest into the mental state of a psychotic serial killer who had murdered six people years before. A psychiatrist has proof that the insanity plea was mishandled, so the execution - set for tomorrow - must be rethought. As the legal teams wait for the killer, they lose contact with his car and driver.<br />Sure enough, the motel picks up their last two occupants for the night: cop number two, Rhodes (Ray Liotta), and his prisoner (Jake Busey). The stage is now set for murder most foul.<br />What makes &quot;Identity&quot; a cleverer-than-most flick is the deft handling of the death-dealing that proceeds sequentially according to room number. When it becomes apparent that the deaths are proceeding numerically even though some appear to have no means by which they could have occurred in that manner, the spooky factor goes up a notch. Could it be that the tormented spirits of long-dead tribe members - yes, the motel was built on an Indian burial ground - are exacting revenge? And what does it mean that everyone at the motel has the same birthday?<br />&quot;Identity&quot; answers these questions with one of the better twist endings you'll see. And for those not satisfied with one mind-bending twist, the filmmakers give you a second one for your money. But sadly, this is where the film goes from the unusual to the cliched, as the second twist is a tried and true slasher gimmick that ultimately costs the film a ratings star.<br />With a firm R-rating for plenty of vulgarity and a host of gruesome murders, &quot;Identity&quot; is certainly not a film for anyone but adults. But the director, James Mangold, deserves some credit for leaving out the anatomical details of the killing process itself, unlike other films in this genre. In truth, no one needs to see just how that baseball bat wound up where it did.<br />The DVD itself is nothing special, though it does give widescreen and full-screen options, plus your choice of the theatrical release or a very slightly modified extended edition. There's filmographies for the actors, deleted scenes, director's commentary, and a very nicely done set of navigation screens. In all, though, fairly typical of what you'll find on most DVD's today.<br />With fine casting, smart writing, solid acting, plenty of twists, and a supernatural element, &quot;Identity&quot; is far from your run-of-the-mill crazed serial killer flick, making it a worthy addition to the collection of slasher, horror, thriller, and mystery film buffs alike.tribe members - yes, the motel was built on an Indian burial ground - are exacting revenge? And what does it mean that everyone at the motel has the same birthday?<br />&quot;Identity&quot; answers these questions with one of the better twist endings you'll see. And for those not satisfied with one mind-bending twist, the filmmakers give you a second one for your money. But sadly, this is where the film goes from the unusual to the cliched, as the second twist is a tried and true slasher gimmick that ultimately costs the film a ratings star.<br />With a firm R-rating for plenty of vulgarity and a host of gruesome murders, &quot;Identity&quot; is certainly not a film for anyone but adults. But the director, James Mangold, deserves some credit for leaving out the anatomical details of the killing process itself, unlike other films in this genre. In truth, no one needs to see just how that baseball bat wound up where it did.<br />The DVD itself is nothing special, though it does give widescreen and full-screen options, plus your choice of the theatrical release or a very slightly modified extended edition. There's filmographies for the actors, deleted scenes, director's commentary, and a very nicely done set of navigation screens. In all, though, fairly typical of what you'll find on most DVD's today.<br />With fine casting, smart writing, solid acting, plenty of twists, and a supernatural element, &quot;Identity&quot; is far from your run-of-the-mill crazed serial killer flick, making it a worthy addition to the collection of slasher, horror, thriller, and mystery film buffs alike.
B000001DTM|5.0|This is a terrific album from U2, with almost every song being memorable and well crafted. B000002U9E|5.0|One of the most powerful music albums ever to be released by a female artist , Kate Bush's \\" Hounds Of Love \\" is an emotionally charged masterpiece . An always honest and challenging personality , Bush displays beautifully her passion over myths , romantism and mysticism on the twelve tracks of this fifth offering of hers . <br />  Divided in two parts , the album starts off with \\" Running Up That Hill \\" , a mysterious love song whose video-clip was unusually brave and dark for that time . An ex-dance student herself , Bush expresses her affection for her other half with some sensual ballet numbers . As for the rest of the tracklist of the \\" Hounds Of Love \\" part , the tittle track becomes strangely addictive with repeated listenings , \\" Cloudbusting \\" remains one of the deepest , most touching songs to have ever hit the charts while \\" Mother Stands For Comfort \\" is a haunting lo-fi gem with Bush whispering \\" Mother will hide the murderer ... mother will stay mum \\" .<br />  The \\" Ninth Wave \\" part obviously tells it's own different story with it's heroin falling asleep , waking up trapped under an icy lake , being executed as a witch and finally being reborn again song after song . \\" And Dream Of Sheep \\" is so rich in feelings , truly magically perfomed by Bush while \\" Jig Of Life \\" is this possesed Celtic perfection with poetry parts read during it's length  . <br />  On deeper analysis there are basically two reasons why \\" Hounds Of Love \\" is so important afterall. Firstly , it sounds as interesting and intense as it did back in 1986 when it was initially released . That was a time when dance divas with steamy sex appeals where sitting on the top places of the charts and there didn't seem to be any room left for something so personal and profound . <br />   Furthermore , Bush was one of the first women to reveal her dark side through her music and she deserves extra credit for that . Ofcourse today there are all these female musicians who will do anything in orderto stand out . Claim that they are depressed , 'sad ' , angry , bisexual ...even mentally disturbed will do just so they can be eccentric and get some attention . Revealing traumas is something like a trend in today's music reality but Bush never really needed to resort to tricks such as these in order to matter . She offered obsessions and raw passion to her public without ever declaring herself a nut . Her multi-dimensional talent shined through . She was a person of her own and that was all . <br />  It's been more than a decade since we last heard of her and there are thousands of fans still hoping for a new Kate Bush record . Various sites on the net inform us that nowadays she enjoys motherhood and a quiet family life . Will she ever release a following to 1992's The Red Shoes ?...Who knows . Fact remains though that her fifth album is flawless , one of those rare records to deserve every five-star review that all these people in here give .

B000002TYX|5.0|It's interesting reading other reviews of this album. I get the impression that some people expected more of it than they got.  This album is in fact an archeological dig into the Beatles'   other unreleased recorded works and a retracing of their early history. It's not a \\"Hits\\" compilation..Go to \\"1\\", \\"1962-66\\" & \\"1967-70\\" if you want that. Instead, what we find here are early demos, live recordings, a failed Audition with Decca (who have probably kicked themselves up the butt every day since January 1 '62), alternate takes, works in progress, unreleased finished recordings and television & radio performances. For a huge fan like myself, this is a treasure trove especially listening to the development of the lads as musicians and performers through the years 1958-1964 which is the period covered in this volume. Yeah the early, scratchily recorded stuff may sound like crap in parts but, putting things in perspective, these guys were 16-18 year olds cutting their teeth on Elvis, Chuck Berry, Little Richard, Buddy Holly, Carl Perkins etc. How many of these types of bands  sounded great at their first rehearsals especially recorded on such primitive equipment? I think any fan disppointment can be waived here! Besides they are a pointer to what was to follow, particularly with the inclusion and first release of \\"In Spite Of All The Danger\\", the first original Beatles song to be recorded.<BR>The alternate versions really are worth a listen. The acapella intro to \\"Eight Days A Week\\" I think is possibly better than the released verison. \\"Leave My Kitten Alone\\" could have been a \\"Beatles For Sale\\" track. \\"One After 909\\" is really interesting in comparison to the released '69 version. The development of songs is the important thing here. There is also the dispelling of myths that the Beatles weren't that good playing live in concert... the Swedish TV performances are quite energetic especially when they could hear themselves play in the early days of Beatlemania. The TV segment with England's briiliant and much loved comedy duo, Morecambe And Wise, is a joy to listen to and even better if you watch it on the DVD. The Beatles hold their own here comedically with 2 very seasoned veterans and the results are really quite funny. <BR>Here was a hungry young band  of 4 working class guys clawing their way to the top, doing what they loved doing. The screaming girls alone only serve as a reminder of what those times and their music meant to a lot of us growing up with the Beatles.<BR>The release of \\"Free As A Bird\\" was much anticipated and it represents the first time that George is given equal lead vocal time on a Beatle track with John And Paul. The track is I think quite strong though it did take a couple of listens to get used to the sound quality. But it's typical Beatles fare that picks up where \\"Abbey Road\\" left off. I get chills every time I hear George's slide guitar kick in and it's beautifully tied in with very \\"Beatlish\\" 3-part harmonies.<BR>Overall this is not the place to start if you're a young person just getting into the Beatles. The album is really quite enjoyable when you take it for what it's meant to be...a great insight into the Beatles at work.
